es.ull.iis.simulation.core
Class Simulation

java.lang.Object
  es.ull.iis.simulation.core.Simulation
All Implemented Interfaces:
Debuggable, Describable, Identifiable, VariableStore, java.lang.Runnable, java.util.concurrent.Callable<java.lang.Integer>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Simulation, Simulation
public abstract class Simulation
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.concurrent.Callable<java.lang.Integer>, java.lang.Runnable, Identifiable, Describable, Debuggable, VariableStore

Main simulation class, identified by means of an identifier and a description. A simulation executes a model defined by means of different structures:

  • ResourceType
  • Resource
  • WorkGroup
  • Activity
  • ElementType
  • Flow
  • TimeDrivenGenerator
A simulation has an associated clock which starts in startTs and advances according to the events produced by the Elements, Resources and TimeDrivenGenerators. A "next-event" technique is used to determine the next timestamp to advance. A minimum TimeUnit determines the accuracy of the simulation's clock. The simulation ends when the simulation clock reaches the endTs timestamp or no more events are available.
Depending on the specific implementation, a simulation can use one or more "worker" threads to execute the event's actions.

A user can interact with this Simulation by filling in some user methods that are activated in different instants:

  • Just before the simulation starts init()
  • Just after the simulation ends end()
  • Just before the simulation clock advances beforeClockTick()
  • Just After the simulation clock advances afterClockTick()

A simulation uses InfoReceivers to show results. Those "listeners" can be added by invoking the addInfoReceiver(InfoReceiver) method.

For debugging purposes, an Output can be associated to this simulation, thus defining the destination for error and debug messages.

Author:
Iván Castilla Rodríguez
